unnormalised: ## Environmental News: Mumbai's Waste Woes Get a Tech Boost!
normalised: ## Environmental News: Mumbai's Waste Woes Get a Tech Boost!

unnormalised: Hey folks, ever driven past Deonar dumping ground at, say, 3:00 PM and held your breath? Well, relief might be on the horizon! The BMC is finally rolling out a pilot project using AI to optimize waste collection routes across Bandra. Imagine, fewer garbage trucks clogging up Linking Road!
normalised: Hey folks, ever driven past Deonar dumping ground at, say, three P.M. and held your breath? Well, relief might be on the horizon! The B M C is finally rolling out a pilot project using A I to optimize waste collection routes across Bandra. Imagine, fewer garbage trucks clogging up Linking Road!

unnormalised: This initiative, championed by IIT Bombay alumni, aims to reduce fuel consumption by 15% and collection time by a whopping 20%. The pilot started last week, on 10/10/2024, and early reports are promising.
normalised: This initiative, championed by I I T Bombay alumni, aims to reduce fuel consumption by fifteen percent and collection time by a whopping twenty percent. The pilot started last week, on tenth october two thousand and twenty four, and early reports are promising.

unnormalised: They're using sensors in bins and predictive analytics to plan routes, ensuring no bin overflows onto our precious chowpatty sands. Remember that Swachh Bharat Abhiyan pledge we took way back on 15/08/1947? Looks like we're finally taking it seriously. This isn't just about cleaner streets, it's about a healthier Mumbai for everyone. The projected cost is Rs. 5 crore, but officials believe the long-term savings will be significant. Let's hope this project spreads faster than gossip at a Kitty party and becomes a national model! The full roll out is slated for 09:00 hrs on January 26, 2025.
normalised: They're using sensors in bins and predictive analytics to plan routes, ensuring no bin overflows onto our precious chowpatty sands. Remember that Swachh Bharat Abhiyan pledge we took way back on fifteenth august nineteen forty seven? Looks like we're finally taking it seriously. This isn't just about cleaner streets, it's about a healthier Mumbai for everyone. The projected cost is rupee five crore, but officials believe the long-term savings will be significant. Let's hope this project spreads faster than gossip at a Kitty party and becomes a national model! The full roll out is slated for nine hundred hours on january twenty six, two thousand and twenty five.
